questions.question_text: Which of the following scenarios should raise a concern about auditor independence?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
For auditors to maintain independence, they should avoid situations that could be perceived as compromising their judgment. In this case, consulting on the implementation creates a conflict of interest.

Selected Answer: D
D. The auditor has a personal relationship with an end user.

Auditor independence is a critical aspect of the auditing process to ensure that auditors can provide unbiased and objective opinions about the financial statements and other matters they are auditing. In this context, a personal relationship between the auditor and an end user (client personnel) can raise concerns about independence because it may compromise the auditor's ability to remain impartial and objective when evaluating the client's financial information. Such a relationship can create the perception that the auditor may not be able to provide an unbiased assessment of the client's financial statements or internal controls. Therefore, option D is the scenario that should raise a concern about auditor independence.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST way for an IS auditor to determine whether an organization’s disaster recovery plan (DRP) is current?

choices.A: Review critical system documentation and related recovery time objectives (RTOs).
choices.B: Verify the DRP identifies appropriate staff with up-to-date contact details.
choices.D: Verify the DRP is periodically tested.
choices.C: Ensure all staff is trained on business continuity.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The BEST way for an IS auditor to determine whether an organization's disaster recovery plan (DRP) is current is option D: Verify the DRP is periodically tested.

While all of the options mentioned are important aspects of assessing the effectiveness and currency of a disaster recovery plan (DRP), periodic testing is crucial.

A. Reviewing critical system documentation and related recovery time objectives (RTOs) is essential, but it doesn't guarantee that the DRP is current. The documentation may be accurate, but it might not have been tested or updated recently.
B. Verifying that the DRP identifies appropriate staff with up-to-date contact details is important for communication during a disaster, but it alone doesn't ensure the effectiveness of the entire plan.
C. Ensuring that all staff is trained on business continuity is vital for the execution of the DRP, but it doesn't directly address the currency of the plan itself.

Therefore, option D is the best way for an IS auditor to determine whether an organization's DRP is current and capable of serving its intended purpose.

When planning an audit, it is acceptable for an IS auditor to rely on a third-party provider's external audit report on service level management when the:

A. scope and methodology meet audit requirements

Explanation:
A. The most critical factor when relying on a third-party audit report is ensuring that the scope and methodology of that report align with the audit requirements of the IS auditor. If the scope and methodology of the third-party audit report match the auditor's needs, it can provide valuable information and assurance regarding service level management. The other options (B, C, and D) may be important but are not as fundamental as ensuring alignment between the third-party report's scope and methodology and the audit requirements.
